docs.abstract: Hundreds of American commandos and other troops are leaving West Africa even as terrorist attacks intensify and spread across the continent.
docs.snippet: Hundreds of American commandos and other troops are leaving West Africa even as terrorist attacks intensify and spread across the continent.
docs.lead_paragraph: LOUMBILA, Burkina Faso — President Trump has ordered most American troops to withdraw from Syria. He wants to bring home thousands more from Afghanistan. Now hundreds of United States commandos and other forces are leaving West Africa — despite an onslaught of attacks from an increasingly deadly matrix of Islamist fighters.

headline.main: Where Terrorism Is Rising in Africa and the U.S. Is Leaving
headline.print_headline: U.S. Pullback  In West Africa Worries Allies

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

docs.abstract: Public schools advocates and even some DeVos allies denounced the proposal to offer federal tax credits for donations to private school scholarships and other educational programs.
docs.snippet: Public schools advocates and even some DeVos allies denounced the proposal to offer federal tax credits for donations to private school scholarships and other educational programs.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Education Secretary Betsy DeVos on Thursday pitched a $5 billion federal tax credit that would fund scholarships to private schools and other educational programs, throwing her weight behind what will be a difficult legislative undertaking to fund the Trump administration’s signature education initiative.

headline.main: Betsy DeVos Backs $5 Billion in Tax Credits for School Choice
headline.print_headline: DeVos Pitches Tax Credit For Private Education

docs.abstract: At Wolf Point High School in rural Montana, Native American students face the same neglect Native students across the U.S. do as they navigate a school system that has failed American Indians.
docs.snippet: At Wolf Point High School in rural Montana, Native American students face the same neglect Native students across the U.S. do as they navigate a school system that has failed American Indians.
docs.lead_paragraph: This article was reported and written in a collaboration with ProPublica, the nonprofit investigative journalism organization.

headline.main: ‘I Feel Invisible’: Native Students Languish in Public Schools
headline.print_headline: ‘I Feel Invisible’: Natives Languishing in Schools

byline.original: By Erica L. Green, Annie Waldman and Annie Flanagan

docs.abstract: After a New York Times-ProPublica investigation, the Education Department said it would examine whether the Wolf Point School District discriminates against Native students.
docs.snippet: After a New York Times-ProPublica investigation, the Education Department said it would examine whether the Wolf Point School District discriminates against Native students.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — This article is a collaboration between ProPublica and The New York Times.

headline.main: U.S. to Investigate Discrimination Against Native Students on Montana Reservation
headline.print_headline: U.S. to Review Tribes’ Claim Of Racism In Classroom

byline.original: By Annie Waldman and Erica L. Green
